Crunchy Granola.directions: Dissolve the brown sugar in the hot water. Add the oil. Combine the dry ingredients in a large bowl. Mix thoroughly by hand. Add the brown-sugar-and-oil mixture to the dry ingredients; toss to combine. Spread out the granola in a thin layer on a sheet pan. Bake at 200Â°F (90Â°C) until crisp, approximately 1 1/2 to 2 hours. Toss lightly with a metal spatula every 30 minutes. Cool completely at room temperature, then store in an airtight container. Chopped dried fruits, additional nuts or fresh fruits can be added at service time. Serve plain or as a topping on fresh berries and yogurt.
Crunchy Granola.name: Crunchy Granola

Maltaise Sauce.directions: Add to hollandaise 2 fluid ounces (60 milliliters) orange juice and 2 teaspoons (10 milliliters) finely grated orange zest. Blood oranges are traditionally used for this sauce.
Maltaise Sauce.name: Maltaise Sauce

Marchand de Vin Sauce.directions: Reduce 8 fluid ounces (240 milliliters) dry red wine and 2 ounces (60 grams) diced shallots by two-thirds. Then add demi-glace, simmer and strain. Season to taste with salt and pepper.
Marchand de Vin Sauce.name: Marchand de Vin Sauce

Sour Cream Muffins.directions: Cream the butter and sugar until light and fluffy. Stir the eggs in one at a time. Sift the dry ingredients together. Stir the dry ingredients and sour cream, alternately, into the butter mixture in three additions. Stir in the vanilla extract. Portion the batter into greased muffin cups and bake at 350Â°F (180Â°C) until light brown and set, approximately 20 minutes. Allow the muffins to cool briefly in the pan before removing.
Sour Cream Muffins.name: Sour Cream Muffins

Roasted Vegetable Soup.directions: Combine the chopped vegetables with the oil, salt, pepper and thyme. Toss to coat the vege-tables evenly with the oil and seasonings. Spread the vegetables on a sheet pan and roast in a 450Â°F (230Â°C) oven until they are well browned. Remove the vegetables from the oven and place them in a saucepot. Add the stock and roasted garlic purÃ©e. Bring to a boil, reduce to a simmer and cook until all of the vegetables are very tender, approximately 30 minutes. PurÃ©e the soup in batches in a blender or food processor. Strain through a coarse china cap or pass through a food mill. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Serve the soup garnished with chopped parsley and toasted baguette slices.
Roasted Vegetable Soup.name: Roasted Vegetable Soup

Espagnole (Brown Sauce).directions: SautÃ© the mirepoix in the butter until well caramelized. Add the flour and cook to make a brown roux. Add the stock and tomato purÃ©e. Stir to break up any lumps of roux. Bring to a boil; reduce to a simmer. Add the sachet. Simmer for approximately 11â„2 hours, allowing the sauce to reduce. Skim the surface as needed to remove impurities. Strain the sauce through a china cap lined with several layers of cheesecloth. Adjust season-ings and cool in a water bath or hold for service.
Espagnole (Brown Sauce).name: Espagnole (Brown Sauce)

Powdered Sugar Glaze.directions: Combine all ingredients in a small bowl. Stir to blend thoroughly and dissolve any lumps. Cover and store at room temperature
Powdered Sugar Glaze.name: Powdered Sugar Glaze

Aunt Ruthie's Pot Roast.directions: Heat the oil in a large rondeau. Add the beef and brown thoroughly. Remove and reserve the brisket. Add the onions and garlic to the pan and sautÃ©. Add the stock and tomato sauce to the pan. Return the brisket to the pan, cover tightly and bring to a boil. Braise at 325Â°F (160Â°C) for 11â„2 hours, basting or turning the brisket often. Combine the remaining ingredients and add to the pan. Continue cooking and basting the brisket until tender, approximately 1 hour. Add additional stock or water as needed during braising. Remove the brisket, degrease the sauce and adjust its consistency and seasonings. Do not strain the sauce. Slice the brisket against the grain and serve with the sauce.
Aunt Ruthie's Pot Roast.name: Aunt Ruthie's Pot Roast

Tulipe Cookies.directions: Melt the unsalted butter and place in the bowl of a mixer fitted with the paddle attachment. Add the sugar and blend until almost smooth. Add the flour and blend until smooth. With the mixer running, add the egg whites very slow-ly. Beat until blended, but do not incorporate air into the batter. Strain the batter through a china cap and set aside to cool completely. Coat several sheet pans with melted butter or line with silicone mats. Spread the dough into 6-inch (15-centimeter) circles on the pans. Bake at 400Â°F (200Â°C) until the edges are brown and the dough is dry, approximately 12 to 18 minutes. To shape into cups, lift the hot cookies off the sheet pan one at a time with an offset spatula. Immediately place over an inverted glass and top with a ramekin or small bowl. The cookies cool very quickly, becoming firm and crisp. The cookie cups can be used for serving ice cream, crÃ¨me brÃ»lÃ©e, fruit or other items.

Puff Pastry.directions: To form the dÃ©trempe, sift the flour and salt together in a large bowl. Cut the cold butter into small pieces and then cut the pieces into the flour until the mixture resembles coarse cornmeal. Make a well in the center of the mixture and add all the water at once. Using a rubber spatula or your fingers, gradually draw the flour into the water. Mix until all the flour is incorporated. Do not knead. The dÃ©trempe should be sticky and shaggy-looking. Turn the dÃ©trempe out onto a lightly floured surface. Knead the dough a few times by hand, rounding it into a ball. Wrap the dough tightly in plastic and chill overnight. To roll in the butter, first prepare the softened butter by placing it between two sheets of plas-tic wrap. Use a rolling pin to roll the softened butter into a rectangle, approximately 5 inches ï‚´ 8 inches (12.5 centimeters ï‚´ 20 centimeters). It is important that the dÃ©trempe and butter be of almost equal consistency. If necessary, allow the dÃ©trempe to sit at room temperature to soften or chill the butter briefly to harden. On a lightly floured board, roll the dÃ©trempe into a rectangle approximately 12 inches ï‚´ 15 inches (30 centimeters ï‚´ 37.5 centimeters). Lift and rotate the dough as necessary to prevent sticking. Use a dry pastry brush to brush away any flour from the doughâ€™s surface. Loose flour can cause gray streaks and can prevent the puff pastry from rising properly when baked. Peel one piece of plastic wrap from the butter. Position the butter in the center of the rectan-gle and remove the remaining plastic. Fold the four edges of the dÃ©trempe over the butter, en-closing it completely. Stretch the dough if necessary; it is important that none of the butter be exposed. With the folded side facing up, press the dough several times with a rolling pin. Use a rock-ing motion to create ridges in the dough. Place the rolling pin in each ridge and slowly roll back and forth to widen the ridge. Repeat until all the ridges are doubled in size. Using the ridges as a starting point, roll the dough out into a smooth, even rectangle approx-imately 8 inches ï‚´ 24 inches (20 centimeters ï‚´ 60 centimeters). Be careful to keep the corners of the dough as right angles. 10. Use a dry pastry brush to remove any loose flour from the doughâ€™s surface. Fold the dough in thirds, like a business letter. If one end is damaged or in worse condition, fold it in first; oth-erwise, start at the bottom. This completes the first turn. 11. Rotate the block of dough 90 degrees so that the folded edge is on your left and the dough faces you like a book. Roll out the dough again, repeating the ridging technique. Once again, the dough should be in a smooth, even rectangle of approximately 8 inches ï‚´ 24 inches (20 centimeters ï‚´ 60 centimeters). 12. Fold the dough in thirds again, completing the second turn. Cover the dough with plastic wrap and chill for at least 30 minutes. 13. Repeat the rolling and folding technique until the dough has had a total of five turns. Do not perform more than two turns without a resting and chilling period. Cover the dough com-pletely and chill overnight before shaping and baking.

Pepper Steak.directions: Season the steaks with salt. Spread the peppercorns in a hotel pan and press the steaks into them, lightly coating each side. Spiced Pecans.directions: Combine the butter, cayenne pepper, cinnamon, salt, Worcestershire sauce and hot sauce. Add the pecan halves and blend well. Blond Roux.directions: Blond roux is cooked slightly longer than white roux and should begin to take on a little color as the flour caramelizes. It is used in ivory-colored sauces, such as veloutÃ©, or where a richer flavor is desired.

Lemongrass Mayonnaise.name: Lemongrass Mayonnaise

They should be the consistency of cornmeal and as dry as possible. Combine with 2 ounces (60 grams) sugar and set aside. Whip the egg whites on medium speed until foamy. Lemon Poppy Seed Muffins.directions: Sift together the flours, baking soda and baking powder. Stir in the poppy seeds and set aside.
